clusters.title: Gen Z risks 'being marginalised' in Madagascar political overhaul as army takes power, expert says
clusters.neutral_headline: Madagascar Military Seizes Power Amid Protests

items.title: Gen Z risks 'being marginalised' in Madagascar political overhaul as army takes power, expert says
items.standfirst: An elite Madagascar military unit said Tuesday it had taken power of the Indian Ocean nation after the national assembly voted to impeach President Andry Rajoelina following weeks of anti-government protests led by young people. Speaking on FRANCE 24, Madagascar expert Dr Luke Freeman of University College London says that Gen Z protesters risk being left out of the overhaul of the political system.
items.content: An elite Madagascar military unit said Tuesday it had taken power of the Indian Ocean nation after the national assembly voted to impeach President Andry Rajoelina following weeks of anti-government protests led by young people. Speaking on FRANCE 24, Madagascar expert Dr Luke Freeman of University College London says that Gen Z protesters risk being left out of the overhaul of the political system.

It is not known where Rajoelina recorded his…

items.title: Military seizes power in Madagascar following anti-government protests
items.standfirst: The army in Madagascar seized power on Tuesday, days after the president went into hiding saying he feared for his life after several weeks of massive anti-government protests.
items.content: The army in Madagascar seized power on Tuesday, days after the president went into hiding saying he feared for his life after several weeks of massive anti-government protests. (Image credit: Brian Inganga)

items.title: Elite military unit says it has seized power in Madagascar
items.standfirst: Announcement comes after country’s parliament impeaches president after weeks of anti-government protestsAn elite military unit said it had taken power in Madagascar on Tuesday, after the country’s parliament impeached president Andry Rajoelina after weeks of anti-government protests.Rajoelina, who said on Monday in a Facebook Live video that he had gone into hiding after attempts to kill him, had refused demands to step down, but the demonstrators won the backing of the influential Capsat unit at the weekend. Continue reading...
items.content: Announcement comes after country’s parliament impeaches president after weeks of anti-government protestsAn elite military unit said it had taken power in Madagascar on Tuesday, after the country’s parliament impeached president Andry Rajoelina after weeks of anti-government protests.Rajoelina, who said on Monday in a Facebook Live video that he had gone into hiding after attempts to kill him, had refused demands to step down, but the demonstrators won the backing of the influential Capsat unit at the weekend. Continue reading...

items.content: The military promises elections within two years, but President Rajoelina insists he is still in charge.

items.title: Madagascar military announces it has taken power amid mass protests
items.standfirst: An elite Madagascar military unit said it has taken power in the country after the national assembly voted to impeach President Andry Rajoelina on October 14, 2025. Earlier in the day, the president had announced the dissolution of the lower house in a failed attempt to block the vote.
items.content: An elite Madagascar military unit said it has taken power in the country after the national assembly voted to impeach President Andry Rajoelina on October 14, 2025. Earlier in the day, the president had announced the dissolution of the lower house in a failed attempt to block the vote.

items.title: Who is in charge of Madagascar after President Rajoelina flees?
items.standfirst: Rajoelina's move to flee the country and dissolve the parliament from exile has created a political crisis amid unrest.
items.content: Rajoelina's move to flee the country and dissolve the parliament from exile has created a political crisis amid unrest.

items.content: A colonel from an elite army unit in Madagascar says the military has taken control of the country.

items.title: Madagascar army says it has taken control after National Assembly votes to impeach President Rajoelina
Madagascar plunges into uncertainty after President flees the country
items.standfirst: Amidst mass protests in Madagascar, President Rajoelina signed a decree dissolving Parliament, before fleeing the country. It is now up to the courts to decide whether this dissolution is legal: if that's the case, MPs could call an extraordinary session to impeach the absent leader. FRANCE 24 's Gaëlle Borgia tells us more from Antananarivo.
items.content: Amidst mass protests in Madagascar, President Rajoelina signed a decree dissolving Parliament, before fleeing the country. It is now up to the courts to decide whether this dissolution is legal: if that's the case, MPs could call an extraordinary session to impeach the absent leader. FRANCE 24 's Gaëlle Borgia tells us more from Antananarivo.

items.title: Madagascar president says he fled country in fear for his life
items.standfirst: Andry Rajoelina does not announce resignation in speech broadcast on social media after military rebellionMadagascar’s president, Andry Rajoelina, said he had fled the country in fear for his life after a military rebellion but did not announce his resignation in a speech broadcast on social media late on Monday from an undisclosed location.The 51-year-old has faced weeks of gen Z-led anti-government protests, which reached a pivotal point on Saturday when an elite military unit joined the protests and called for the president and other ministers to step down. That prompted Rajoelina to say that an illegal attempt to seize power was under way in the Indian Ocean island and to leave the country. Continue reading...
items.content: Andry Rajoelina does not announce resignation in speech broadcast on social media after military rebellionMadagascar’s president, Andry Rajoelina, said he had fled the country in fear for his life after a military rebellion but did not announce his resignation in a speech broadcast on social media late on Monday from an undisclosed location.The 51-year-old has faced weeks of gen Z-led anti-government protests, which reached a pivotal point on Saturday when an elite military unit joined the protests and called for the president and other ministers to step down. That prompted Rajoelina to say that an illegal attempt to seize power was under way in the Indian Ocean island and to leave the country. Continue reading...

ai_summary: An elite military unit in Madagascar announced it seized power after parliament impeached the president.
The president went into hiding, citing safety concerns, but refused to resign from his position.
Anti-government protests led by young people have been ongoing for several weeks in the country.
The military has promised elections within two years, but the president insists he is still in charge.
A Madagascar expert suggests Gen Z protesters risk being excluded from political changes.

items.title: ‘Freedom is priceless’: Emotional return for liberated Palestinian prisoners
items.standfirst: With huge crowds waiting to welcome them home, Palestinian prisoners released by Israel on Monday were overwhelmed with joy as they returned to their loved ones. Israel freed about 1,700 Palestinian prisoners and 250 security detainees in exchange for 20 hostages held by Hamas, under the first phase of the Gaza ceasefire deal.
items.content: With huge crowds waiting to welcome them home, Palestinian prisoners released by Israel on Monday were overwhelmed with joy as they returned to their loved ones. Israel freed about 1,700 Palestinian prisoners and 250 security detainees in exchange for 20 hostages held by Hamas, under the first phase of the Gaza ceasefire deal.

items.title: Trump says new strike kills six 'narcoterrorists' off Venezuela
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump said Tuesday that a strike on a vessel allegedly smuggling drugs from Venezuela to the United States killed six “narcoterrorists”, bringing the total death toll in such operations to at least 27. Many experts question the legality of using lethal force in international waters against suspects who have not been charged.

items.title: Suspect in US arson attack at Pennsylvania governor’s mansion pleads guilty

items.content: Cody Balmer told police he had planned to attack Democratic Governor Josh Shapiro with a sledgehammer at his home.

items.title: Pennsylvania man pleads guilty in arson attack at governor’s mansion while Shapiro’s family slept
items.standfirst: Under a plea deal, Cody Balmer was sentenced to 25 to 50 years in prison.
items.content: A man who scaled an iron security fence in the middle of the night, eluded police and used beer bottles filled with gasoline to ignite the occupied Pennsylvania governor’s mansion pleaded guilty Tuesday to attempted murder and other charges. Cody Balmer, 38, also entered pleas to terrorism, 22 counts of arson, aggravated arson, burglary, aggravated assault of Gov. Josh Shapiro, 21 counts of reckless endangerment and loitering in the April 13 attack that did millions of dollars in damage to the state-owned brick building. Under a plea deal, Balmer was sentenced to 25 to 50 years in prison. Shapiro and members of his family had to be awakened and evacuated, but no one was injured. The multiple endangerment charges reflected the number of people in the residence at the time, including the governor’s family, guests and state troopers. The fire was set hours after they celebrated the Jewish holiday of Passover with a Seder in the residence. Prosecutors played video clips that showed Molotov cocktails going off and a figure inside and outside the residence. Judge Deborah Curcillo called the video “horrific” and “very frightening.” Balmer told police he planned to beat Shapiro with a small sledgehammer if he had encountered him after breaking into the building, according to court documents. Balmer turned himself in the next afternoon to face charges of attempted homicide, terrorism, aggravated arson and aggravated assault. Police say Balmer broke in through the southern wing of the residence, into a room often used to entertain crowds and display art. Investigators recovered two broken glass beer bottles containing gasoline. The fire charred walls, tables, buffet serving dishes, plates and a piano. Window panes and brick around doors and windows were also damaged. Shapiro's Jewish faith and the attack during the Passover weekend raised questions about Balmer's motivation, but Balmer told The Associated Press in a May letter from jail that had not been a factor in his decision. “He can be Jewish, Muslim, or a purple people eater for all I care and as long as he leaves me and mine alone,” Balmer wrote. He said in a brief June 9 video interview from Camp Hill State Prison that he did think beforehand about whether children might be injured. “Does anyone ever consider children?” Balmer said in June. “It doesn't seem that way. I sure as hell did. I'm glad no one got hurt.” Asked why he felt Shapiro had somehow done him wrong, Balmer replied: “I'm not going to answer that.” Balmer’s mother said days after his arrest that she had tried to get him assistance for mental health issues, but “nobody would help.” Court proceedings had been delayed while he received mental health treatment, his lawyer has said. At a court hearing a few days after the fire, Balmer told a judge he was an unemployed welder with no income or savings and “a lot of children.” The residence, built in 1968, did not have sprinklers. Work to fix the damage and to bolster its security features continues.

ai_summary: A man pleaded guilty to attempted murder for setting fire to the Pennsylvania governor's mansion.
The arson occurred while Governor Josh Shapiro and his family were sleeping inside the residence.
The suspect, Cody Balmer, will face a minimum of 25 years in prison under the plea deal.
Balmer admitted he planned to attack Governor Shapiro with a sledgehammer.
Governor Shapiro stated that explaining the incident to his children has been the hardest part.

clusters.title: Second time a charm? French PM Lecornu offers concessions to hostile parliament
clusters.neutral_headline: Second time a charm? French PM Lecornu offers concessions to hostile parliament

items.title: Second time a charm? French PM Lecornu offers concessions to hostile parliament
items.standfirst: Was it enough for France’s minority government to pass the first hurdle of a trigger-happy hostile parliament that can pass a vote of no-confidence at any time? Reappointed prime minister Sébastien Lecornu offering a suspension of Emmanuel Macron's flagship reform, the raising of the retirement age. We'll review the general policy speech of a Lecornu who this time at least made it to the National Assembly. Last week, his initial coalition government imploded spectacularly after a mere 14 hours.
items.content: Was it enough for France’s minority government to pass the first hurdle of a trigger-happy hostile parliament that can pass a vote of no-confidence at any time? Reappointed prime minister Sébastien Lecornu offering a suspension of Emmanuel Macron's flagship reform, the raising of the retirement age. We'll review the general policy speech of a Lecornu who this time at least made it to the National Assembly. Last week, his initial coalition government imploded spectacularly after a mere 14 hours.

items.title: French PM suspends Macron’s pension plan before no-confidence vote
items.standfirst: Sébastien Lecornu hopes delaying changes until after 2027 election will win him enough support to surviveFrance’s prime minister, Sébastien Lecornu, has suspended Emmanuel Macron’s flagship 2023 pension overhaul until after the 2027 presidential election in the hope of winning over enough Socialist deputies to survive a no-confidence vote.In a welcome respite for the embattled French president, the left-leaning party, which holds the balance of power in a deeply divided parliament, suggested in response on Tuesday that it would not back any of the no-confidence motions to be voted on later this week. Continue reading...
items.content: Sébastien Lecornu hopes delaying changes until after 2027 election will win him enough support to surviveFrance’s prime minister, Sébastien Lecornu, has suspended Emmanuel Macron’s flagship 2023 pension overhaul until after the 2027 presidential election in the hope of winning over enough Socialist deputies to survive a no-confidence vote.In a welcome respite for the embattled French president, the left-leaning party, which holds the balance of power in a deeply divided parliament, suggested in response on Tuesday that it would not back any of the no-confidence motions to be voted on later this week. Continue reading...

items.title: French prime minister backs suspending unpopular pension reform law
items.standfirst: Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu faces two no-confidence motions this week as France's political crisis deepens.
items.content: Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu faces two no-confidence motions this week as France's political crisis deepens.

items.title: Key takeaways from French PM Sébastien Lecornu's policy speech
items.standfirst: French Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu on Tuesday said he would suspend France's deeply unpopular pension reform in a bid to keep his fragile government afloat and end months of political turmoil. The move aims to win over Socialist Party lawmakers who threatened to join left- and right-wing efforts to topple his cabinet, which took office on Monday.
items.content: French Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu on Tuesday said he would suspend France's deeply unpopular pension reform in a bid to keep his fragile government afloat and end months of political turmoil. The move aims to win over Socialist Party lawmakers who threatened to join left- and right-wing efforts to topple his cabinet, which took office on Monday.

items.title: France: PM Lecornu suspends controversial pension reform
items.standfirst: Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu told parliament on Tuesday that controversial plans for pension reform would be delayed until after the 2027 French presidential election. Lecornu's government, which took office on Monday, is already facing no-confidence motions tabled by the left-wing France Unbowed and far-right National Rally.
items.content: Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu told parliament on Tuesday that controversial plans for pension reform would be delayed until after the 2027 French presidential election. Lecornu's government, which took office on Monday, is already facing no-confidence motions tabled by the left-wing France Unbowed and far-right National Rally.

items.title: French PM announces the pension reform will be suspended until the presidential election
items.standfirst: In his address to French MPs, Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu announced the pension reform would be suspended until the 2027 presidential election. As he outlined the new government's priorities, he also confirmed he would not be using the 49.3 law and wanted to build bridges beyond party lines. FRANCE 24's Marc Perelman looks into what was said, ahead of the no-confidence vote on Thursday.
items.content: In his address to French MPs, Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu announced the pension reform would be suspended until the 2027 presidential election. As he outlined the new government's priorities, he also confirmed he would not be using the 49.3 law and wanted to build bridges beyond party lines. FRANCE 24's Marc Perelman looks into what was said, ahead of the no-confidence vote on Thursday.

items.title: Sébastien Lecornu bets on a government of technical ministers
items.standfirst: Sébastien Lecornu's second cabinet in a week includes several members who served in previous governments, but the Prime Minister is placing his bets on civil society representatives. The far right and radical left both said they will file a no-confidence motion in parliament.
items.content: Sébastien Lecornu's second cabinet in a week includes several members who served in previous governments, but the Prime Minister is placing his bets on civil society representatives. The far right and radical left both said they will file a no-confidence motion in parliament.

ai_summary: French Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu offered concessions to a hostile parliament.
Lecornu suspended Emmanuel Macron's pension reform to try and keep his government afloat.
The suspension aims to win over Socialist Party lawmakers and avoid no-confidence votes.
Lecornu's initial coalition government imploded after only 14 hours in the previous week.
The French prime minister faces two no-confidence motions this week as the crisis deepens.

items.title: JP Morgan boss says more ‘cockroaches’ will emerge after private credit sector failures
items.standfirst: Jamie Dimon expects further weak links in ‘shadow banking’ sector to be revealed after collapse of two US firmsThe boss of JP Morgan, Jamie Dimon, has warned over further losses linked to the private credit sector, saying more “cockroaches” could emerge after the collapse of the sub-prime auto lender Tricolor and the car parts supplier First Brands.The bank said on Tuesday that although it had no exposure to First Brands, which sells car parts across the US, it had taken a $170m (£128m) hit from Tricolor, which collapsed amid fraud allegations last month. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel limits aid and keeps Rafah crossing closed in dispute over hostage remains
items.standfirst: Tensions still high as Israel accuses Hamas of breaching agreement by withholding bodies of 24 hostagesGaza ceasefire – live updatesThe fragile ceasefire in Gaza faced its first test on Tuesday when Israel said the flow of aid into the devastated Palestinian territory would be cut by half and the crucial Rafah border crossing with Egypt would not open as planned, accusing Hamas of breaching the US-brokered agreement by withholding the bodies of Israeli hostages.On Monday, Israelis celebrated the return of the last 20 living hostages in Gaza and Palestinians rejoiced at Israel’s release of nearly 2,000 detainees as part of the ceasefire’s first phase. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: Returning the bodies of 28 hostages was part of the ceasefire deal between Israel and Hamas but only four have been handed overGaza ceasefire – live updatesThe families of missing dead Israeli hostages have written to the US special envoy Steve Witkoff to urge him to “pull out every stop and leave no stone unturned” in forcing Hamas to bring their relatives home from Gaza.The return of 28 dead hostages was part of the agreement that ushered in a ceasefire, but only four have so far been handed over. Continue reading...
items.content: Returning the bodies of 28 hostages was part of the ceasefire deal between Israel and Hamas but only four have been handed overGaza ceasefire – live updatesThe families of missing dead Israeli hostages have written to the US special envoy Steve Witkoff to urge him to “pull out every stop and leave no stone unturned” in forcing Hamas to bring their relatives home from Gaza.The return of 28 dead hostages was part of the agreement that ushered in a ceasefire, but only four have so far been handed over. items.title: Hamas searches for missing bodies of Israeli hostages
items.standfirst: The International Committee of the Red Cross said it will take time to hand over the remains of the Israeli hostages killed in the Israel-Hamas war, given the difficulties of finding bodies amid Gaza's rubble. On October 13, 2025 Hamas handed over four bodies - whom the Israeli military said they have now identified - leaving 24 still to be returned under the terms of the ceasefire agreement.
items.content: The International Committee of the Red Cross said it will take time to hand over the remains of the Israeli hostages killed in the Israel-Hamas war, given the difficulties of finding bodies amid Gaza's rubble. On October 13, 2025 Hamas handed over four bodies - whom the Israeli military said they have now identified - leaving 24 still to be returned under the terms of the ceasefire agreement.

The takeover followed US concerns about the CEO.

clusters.neutral_headline: Fragile Gaza Ceasefire Tested After Detainee Swap

items.title: A fragile Gaza ceasefire is tested after Israel and Hamas swap detainees and hostages
items.standfirst: Israel and Hamas took steps toward ending the two-year war that has devastated the Gaza Strip, but hard work lies ahead.
items.content: Israel and Hamas took steps toward ending the two-year war that has devastated the Gaza Strip, but hard work lies ahead.(Image credit: AFP)

items.title: Who are the 20 hostages released by Hamas?
items.standfirst: More than two years after they were abducted during the terrorist attack that launched the Israel-Hamas war, all remaining living hostages have been returned to Israel from the Gaza Strip.
items.content: More than two years after they were abducted during the terrorist attack that launched the Israel-Hamas war, all remaining living hostages have been returned to Israel from the Gaza Strip.

ai_summary: Israel and Hamas exchanged detainees and hostages.
The exchange was a step toward ending the war.
All remaining living hostages have been returned to Israel.
The war has devastated the Gaza Strip.
Hard work remains to achieve a lasting peace.

clusters.title: Three police officers killed in Italy after explosion at house during eviction
clusters.neutral_headline: Three Police Officers Killed in Italy Explosion

items.title: Three police officers killed in Italy after explosion at house during eviction
items.standfirst: Two men and one woman arrested after explosion in Castel d’Azzano, which police believe to have been intentionalAn explosion at a farmhouse near Verona killed three police officers and injured at least 13 others, officials said on Tuesday.Police were attempting to conduct an eviction when the house blew up overnight in Castel d’Azzano, in northern Italy, in what is suspected to be an intentional act of violence. Continue reading...
items.content: Two men and one woman arrested after explosion in Castel d’Azzano, which police believe to have been intentionalAn explosion at a farmhouse near Verona killed three police officers and injured at least 13 others, officials said on Tuesday.Police were attempting to conduct an eviction when the house blew up overnight in Castel d’Azzano, in northern Italy, in what is suspected to be an intentional act of violence. Continue reading...

items.title: Police officers sent to evict three siblings killed in gas explosion in Italy
items.standfirst: Three police officers have been killed after they opened a door to a rural Italian farmhouse that had been intentionally filled with gas, igniting a massive explosion.
items.content: Three police officers have been killed after they opened a door to a rural Italian farmhouse that had been intentionally filled with gas, igniting a massive explosion.

ai_summary: An explosion at a house in Italy killed three police officers.
The officers were attempting an eviction when the explosion occurred.
The explosion happened in Castel d’Azzano near Verona.
Two men and one woman have been arrested.
The explosion is suspected to be an intentional act.

clusters.title: Venezuela to close its Norwegian embassy - days after opposition leader wins Nobel Peace Prize in Oslo
clusters.neutral_headline: Venezuela to Close Its Norwegian Embassy

items.title: Venezuela to close its Norwegian embassy - days after opposition leader wins Nobel Peace Prize in Oslo
items.standfirst: Venezuela is to close its embassy in Norway - just days after the South American country's opposition leader was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in Oslo.
items.content: Venezuela is to close its embassy in Norway - just days after the South American country's opposition leader was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in Oslo.

items.title: Venezuela shuts Norway embassy after opposition leader's Nobel Prize
items.standfirst: Oslo calls the decision "regrettable", stressing that the Nobel committee functions independently.
items.content: Oslo calls the decision "regrettable", stressing that the Nobel committee functions independently.

ai_summary: Venezuela will close its embassy in Norway.
The decision comes after the opposition leader won the Nobel Prize.
Oslo called the decision regrettable.
The Nobel committee functions independently.
The closure reflects strained relations.
